 Who: FeindSlayer vs. any evo

 You keep saying everyone is too chicken to accept your challenge, but I've seen at least 3 or 4 responses telling you to make a formal challenge in the formal debate forum. Hell, Marc has even told you what you need to determine before you make such a challenge. Have you done any of this yet? No. So why should anyone take you seriously if you won't even take the slightest effort to make an actual challenge?

Why: I want to see if any evo can fend for himself against a creo without a team behind him.
with
 
 What a laugh. Your arguments to date are so flimsy and conventional that such a debate would not be worth the effort involved. As a positive theory creation just does not have any merit. Thats why the proponents always end up resorting to the "you cannnot disprove my theory - therefore I am correct" mode rather soon in any such proceeding. Thats all you have left after noting that empirical evidence simply does not support either OEC or YEC.

Being "debated" at by a Creationist is rather like being flogged with a wet noodle -- it doesn't really hurt because it has little substance, but leaves you with this unpleasantly sticky and slimy feeling afterwards. emoticon_xhoho

the proponents always end up resorting to the "you cannnot disprove my theory - therefore I am correct" mode rather soon in any such proceeding. 
 "Grave robbers from outer space... can you prove it didn't happen?!?!"-- Criswell, at the conclusion of the perennial worst movie ever made, "Plan 9 from Outer Space"

All loaded words and absolutely zero acknowledgements. Do you have any confidence in yourselves?
 
 I haven't started any formal debates because I need someone to start with.

I haven't started any formal debates because I need someone to start with.

 That's funny; in the other thread, you insisted that you know how to read and find information on your own. Yet, here, after being told several times to post in the debate section, you haven't. So here's how this works: You post an official challenge in the Debate Challenges forum, and somebody does (or does not) accept the challenge. You find judges, decide terms of the debate, etc. Once the parameters have been set, the debate actually takes place in the Debate Tournaments section.
 
 Considering the above, it is ironic that you are essentially calling everybody a chicken when you're the one strutting around not knowing what you're doing.
 
 But then, if this is any indication, we shan't be expecting much in the way of research from you in your debates...

I haven't started any formal debates because I need someone to start with.

 
 Perhaps thats because you have not yet demonstrated sufficient knowledge or capability to interest anyone. Why kill a fly with an antiaircraft gun after all.

I've posted this challenge in a couple of threads here already, but no evo has been brave enough to accept it:

 
 You haven't posted a challenge yet. Including this post.
 
 
Who: FeindSlayer vs. any evo

 
 Would I fit the bill?
 
 
What: A formal debate challenge

 
 Sure, but about what? What's your resolution?
 
 For instance, you might say "Resolved: Creation and Evolution are equally valid interpretations of empirical evidence".
 
 Now, personally I'd say that's still too vague because 'creation' drags in all kinds of issues that evolution doesn't speak to (eg abiogenesis, cosmology etc), and 'evolution' could mean common descent, the theory of evolution, etc etc. 
 
 So we might kick the idea around for a bit and narrow it down to "Resolved: Hypotheses of special creation of species and common descent are equally well supported by empirical evidence".
 
 Or, perhaps it's the age of the earth you want to focus on: "Resolved: all available evidence is consistent with a 6-10,000 year old earth"
 
 I can't do this for you, feindslayer; make up your mind and present a proper challenge.

The Creationist idea of debate is something along these lines: I post 100 brief random creationist claims and objections to evolution, and if you haven't thoroughly disproved every last one, quoting data and peer-reviewed references, within the allotted space and time, I win! And if by some freak chance you do manage this herculean task, I'll post another 200! And so on and so forth, till you've forgotten the first 100 and I'll recycle them. emoticon_xbouncer 
 
 It's a mug's game. Best just to refute Creationism in general by arguing for a better and more scientific solution, not so much respond to the specific claims they bring up over and over again.
Can I play? How about I list every transitional form from proto-life to human beings, with the requisite genetic changes (how and why), whilst you quote bits of Genesis chapter 1 at me?

Can I play? How about I list every transitional form from proto-life to human beings, with the requisite genetic changes (how and why), whilst you quote bits of Genesis chapter 1 at me?

 
 Nah, nah, nah, that's not how debates with Creationists work. They keep asking such profound questions as: "If we evolved from monkeys, how come there are still monkeys?" -- and sit back smugly triumphant as if evolution has no answer to this unanswerable conundrum. 
 
 There are literally hundreds of these one-liner questions, all of which take time and effort to refute, though all are perfectly refutable. Add to this the fact that Creationist has not the interest in trying to understand the answers, nor (usually) the intellectual background to have a hope of understanding them.
 
 Debate with a Creationist? I think ridicule is far more economical!
Yes, Peeling, you fit the bill. Now I will post my challenge.
